Guppies Disprove Darwinists 
 
 
 In this post I'm going to show how even the simplest experiments/observations on animals destroys the Neo-darwin theory. There's a reason evolutionists don't do tests/studies on real animals....it's because real-world biology crushes their theory. Thus, they normally avoid real-world tests and experiments like the Plague.
 
 Natural Selection Study Shows Animals Can Adapt Dramatically Fast
 
 http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releas...SSS-270397.php
 
 In a unique, real-world test of the theory of evolution, a National Science Foundation (NSF)-supported research team has demonstrated that animals can adapt to sudden changes in their environment with surprising speed. It's a finding that challenges current methods of evaluating evolutionary changes through the fossil record.
 
 The study of wild guppies on the West Indies island of Trinidad, reported in the newest (March 28) issue of the journal Science, found that the fish could evolve between 10,000 and 10 million times faster than the rate of evolution inferred from the fossil record. It suggests that characterizing evolution from the palaeontological record alone may yield a misleading picture. 
 
 So right off the bat, the theory of evolution is in trouble. What is supposed to take thousnds/ millions of years for populations of animals to evolve has just taken a swift punch to the gut by David Reznick. 
 
 See what's happening with this is experiment is that David Reznick has noticed that guppies, upon being placed in an environment with predators, grow larger quicker and give birth to larger offspring. Of course he hasn't tested what actually CAUSED this phenomenon to happen, he's merely observed it in the population and is blindly attributing it to evolutionists' holy creator, Natural Selection. And being the good evolutionist that he is, Mr. Reznick is falling in line nicely with the current theory by suggesting that these guppies evolved through death of the "unfit."
 
 But is there is another way? Well of course there is! And it has nothing to do with death or which fish goes on to breed and which doesn't. As I have posted in here before, the following link shows that many animals have the miraculous ability to evolve during development according to external conditions - including the ability to grow larger when their environment dictates that they need to be so:
 
 http://www.fiu.edu/~donnelly/termpaperex1.pdf#search='plasticity%20body%20struc ture'
 
 ..... Flatworms (Phagocotus gracilis) were used as
 predators or predator chemical cues upon salamander larvae (Ambystoma texanum and Ambystoma barbouri). The presence of the flatworms and their cues induced the eggs to delay their hatching time. This resulted in larger, and more advanced hatchlings. This finding supports the earlier field observations that the flatworm preyed heavily on smaller, less developed hatchlings. This shift in hatch time is adaptive and supports greater hatchling survival (Sih and Moore 1993).
 
 But not only that, but many animals can actually alter their COLOR based on predators.
 
 in response to the presence of a predatory dragonfly (Aesha umbrosa). The larvae that were reared in the presence of the predator differed in shape and in color than those that were reared in predator free environments. The treatments exposed tadpoles to tail damage and to chemical cues of the dragonfly feeding on conspecifics. The tadpoles responded plastically by altering their color and tail shape. The tail was extended, presumably increasing swimming speed and hence survivorship. The color change was seen in the tail. The appearance of color on the tail is thought to attract predatory attacks on the tail rather than on the body.
 
 So here we have a problem! David Reznick says that the guppies evolved through natural selection, yet we know that many animals can evolve instantly in the egg to accomplish the same thing. Same sets of genes. Different phenotypes. Genes don't dictate life. Life dictates genes. Evolutionists have it all backwards. 
 
 And you know what the kicker is? This is not a mechanism that can be ADDED to the theory...as some might insist.....instead, it's a mechanism that REPLACES the whole theory. And the reason it replaces it is because it dismantles the need for selection - which is the lifeline of evolutionists. And the reason it dismantles selection is because God created every creature with this adaptive ability -- which gives them all the same traits and makes them all the same "fitness" upon the same environemental cue. 
 
 Without selection, this theory withers on the vine.
 
 But this thing is really a double edge sword for you evolutionists. There are a couple more things about the article that I find interesting.
 
 The first is this: Notice how Mr. Reznick calls this "Evolution."
 
 In a unique, real-world test of the theory of evolution, a National Science Foundation (NSF)-supported research team has demonstrated that animals can adapt to sudden changes in their environment with surprising speed.
 
 Why is this important? Because this implies whatever physiological changes happened, happened over generations. In otherwords, this was a heritable thing. It wasn't a study where Mr. Resnick set out to observe simple plasticity. No, his goal, as stated, was to study evolution. -and that's exactly what he saw.
 
 Thus, what we have is not an addition to Neodarwinism, but a substitution.
 
 Not only that....but if you are to believe "every paleontologist since Cuvier" you would also have to acknowledge that the fossil record does not show a gradual change in animals. On the contrary, it shows long periods of stasis, interupted by short periods of rapid physiological change upon an enviornmental shift.
 
 Gould states...
 
 The fundamental reason why a lot of paleontologists don't care much for gradualism is because the fossil record doesn't show gradual change and every paleontologist has known that ever since Cuvier. If you want to get around that you have to invoke the imperfection of the fossil record. Every paleontologist knows that most species don't change. That's bothersome if you are trained to believe that evolution ought to be gradual. In fact it virually precludes your studying the very process you went into the school to study. Again, because you don't see it, that brings terrible distress." Steven Jay Gould
 
 "The fossil record is full of gaps and disconinuities, but they are all attributed to the notorious imperfection of the fossil record. The fossil record is imperfect, but I think that is not an adequate explanation...one thing it does show that cannot be attributed to its imperfection is that most species don't change...they may get a little bigger or bumpier but they remain the same species and that's not due to imperfection and gaps but stasis. And yet this remarkable stasis has generally been ignored as no data. If they don't change, it's not evolution so you don't talk about it. Steven Jay Gould
 
 And guess what we see with the guppies? We see a rapid physiological change upon an enviornmental cue.
 
 Finally, in the article, Reznick does make the following brilliant observation with which I agree with totally:
 
 Such studies are important because people tend to think of evolution as a historical process that is not subject to experiments. It is the scarcity of experiments that is the source of some of the criticism of the theory.
 
 That is the understatement of the century. THIS is why evolutionists don't do these types of tests....because they EXPOSE themselves when they do them. 
 
 This theory of evolution is nothing but a made-up piece of baloney. They've replaced God's plan of giving each creature adaptive abilities, which help them fit in with a changing environment, with a twisted plan that requires death (before breeding) to any creature that happens to be unfit.
 
 This is the beautiful truth...and evolutionists simply cannot get around it. That's why most evolutionists would probably just assume people like David Reznick keep their mouths shut.
Symbiote

The theory of evolution does not demand it take place at any particular pace... in stable conditions we expect it to usually take place very slowly, in conditions of great change, eg the introduction of new predators, climate change, much faster..
 
 No biologist denies that organisms can change their physical characteristics for reasons unrelated to their gene pool, for example, people can become obese by eating large quantities of food (One of God's Beautiful Miracles nodoubt), the idea that this "disproves" evolution has no basis in fact at all.
 
 The only thing you have proven (yet again) is your complete ignorance of something you spend a lot of time talking about. Try shutting your mouth and opening a book once in a while.
 
 The key to understanding that evolution, not some vague notion of plasticity is responsible for these particular changes is the fact they took place over the span of generations. Once dropped in a pool with fewer predators, fish did not transform instantaneously into larger creatures that lived longer - nor did their children, the change took place bit by bit over generatios. The "plasticity" theory cannot explain why the 7th generation fish exhibited more of these characteristics than the 4th generation fish.
pandion

I've suspected it all along and now I'm sure. You are nothing more than a parrot. I have thought so because you never defend your views. You just post your tripe and repeat it over and over again, without any apparent ability to defend it or even to explain it. Now comes the clincher. Your link doesn't work. Do you know why? Because it is a cut and paste. Your little piece was written by someone else and you are just stealing it and posting it as your own. Even worse, your link (had it been complete) is to a press release and not even the actual article.
 
 The article in question is:
 
 Reznick DN, Shaw FH, Rodd FH, Shaw RG. "Evaluation of the rate of evolution in natural populations of guppies (Poecilia reticulata)." Science, 1997, 275: 1934-1937.
 
 Abstract
 Natural populations of guppies were subjected to an episode of directional selection that mimicked natural processes. The resulting rate of evolution of age and size at maturity was similar to rates typically obtained for traits subjected to artificial selection in laboratory settings and up to seven orders of magnitude greater than rates inferred from the paleontological record. Male traits evolved more rapidly than female traits largely because males had more genetic variation upon which natural selection could act. These results are considered in light of the ongoing debate about the importance of natural selection versus other processes in the paleontological record of evolution.
 
 You can find the article on the Science web site. That has links to the article if you have a subscription or access. You can also find information about it all over the web. Just Google the title. You'll get about 268 hits, many with information about the science involved.
 
 My bet is that supersport didn't have the ganas to actually read the article that he cites. He's just a parrot.
 
So right off the bat, the theory of evolution is in trouble.
Why is that? Do you understand what the hypothesis of the experiment was?
 
What is supposed to take thousnds/ millions of years for populations of animals to evolve has just taken a swift punch to the gut by David Reznick.
Well, yes. Eleven years is quite swift, but it actually supports the theory of evolution through natural selection. The estimates of the speed of evolution that you seem to be depending on were done by George Gaylord Simpson way back in the 1940s or 1950s. Since then, we have observed fruit flies, as well as other specimens, to evolve quite rapidly, showing significant evolution in only a decade or so. More recently, however, scientists have been able to observe evolution in natural settings and have found that it can sometimes be quite rapid when environmental change is rapid. Besides the studies that Reznick did on guppies, there are also the studies of the Galapagos finches by the grants, and studies of anole lizards in the Bahamas. These are observable phenotypical changes, not speciation events.
 
See what's happening with this is experiment is that David Reznick has noticed that guppies, upon being placed in an environment with predators, grow larger quicker and give birth to larger offspring.
Horse pucky. He noticed no such thing. What he noticed was that downstream guppies, where predators were numerous, were smaller and quicker to mature than upstream guppies, where predators were rare.
 
Of course he hasn't tested what actually CAUSED this phenomenon to happen, he's merely observed it in the population and is blindly attributing it to evolutionists' holy creator, Natural Selection.
As I suspected. You didn't have the ganas to educate yourself and actually read the paper. Actually, what Reznick did was exactly what you said he didn't. He spent 11 years in testing his hypothesis.
 
And being the good evolutionist that he is, Mr. Reznick is falling in line nicely with the current theory by suggesting that these guppies evolved through death of the "unfit."
No he's not. He said no such thing. Why don't you explain to us what factors he use to recognize the unfit.
 
 What a parrot! You're just plain dishonest.

You haven't read the paper. His experiments were all done in natural environments over 11 years. You are inventing things that aren't true. That makes you a liar on top of everything else.
Hi_Its_Me

Why you think that any animal can be pre-adapted to new predators, I don't know. Certainly no biologist thinks that.
 
 Baby animals are, in general, adapted to the same things that their parents were. They are not, however, exactly the same, as there is variation.
 For the guppies, some babies were larger than others, and some adults had fewer babies. The largest babies tended to survive better, being able to move farther for food, so there were more of them that reached reproductive age.
 If a larger number of predators were involved, the guppies that had more babies would have a higher chance, statistically, of passing their genes on.
 This process is quite fast, and if you did some research (especially on punctuated equilibrium), you would find that this information is not as devastating to evolution as you thought.
 
 Two last thoughts: I haven't seen anyone but supersport posting lately. What happened to creationists with rational arguments?
 Also, thank you, supersport, for providing a well documented instance of evolution. I guess the peppered moth example was getting old...

 They don't exist. That's a contradiction in terms.

 I think I know where your head has been lodged but I will refrain from saying it here. You obviously missed the whole part I cut-and-pasted about tadpoles. You need to do some reading on Evo Devo.
 
 In polyphenic development, hormones control a switch between alternative developmental pathways so that individuals with identical genotypes can develop dramatically different phenotypes. The hormones that control polyphenic development (juvenile hormone, ecdysteroids, and a few neurohormones) are the same as those that control insect metamorphosis. Hence an understanding of the endocrine regulation of metamorphosis has proven essential for understanding the control of polyphenic developmental switches. 
 
 http://www.biology.duke.edu/nijhout/polyphenism.htm
 
 
 Your silly theory is way outdated. Get with the times, man.

 I believe each organism was created with intelligent design and inherent wisdom. Each animal has an adaptive phenotype so that they can multiply and fill the earth by spreading out into many different environments and habitats. The advantage of this is obvious: Rather than having to wait thousands or millions of years for the correct mutation to provide the necessary genes, animals were created so they could adjust themselves on-the-fly to changing environments.....and then if these environments continue, the biological adjustments will be passed on to future generations. 
 
 It's a brilliantly simple idea that science simply refuses to test. In fact, this concept petrifies evolutionists to the core. Have you ever noticed how neo-darwinists never even discuss adaptive phenotypes or the ability of new traits to arise during development via the environment? Never. Oh, occasionally you might hear the word "saltationism" or "Lamarckism" thrown about in a negative tone, but evolutionists rarely have the guts to face reality to dive into these subjects deeply. In fact, I have never read an in-debth discussion about plasticity or environmentally induced biological changes in a neo-darwinist's book. And it's not that these people are dumb.....They're just simply too afraid to go there, in fear of planting seeds in people's minds. Their whole world-view depends on people's faith in their thoery -- and that there are no reasonable alternatives. So they just play like the alternative isn't there. 
 
 But if it can shown that animals' evolve/change in a different way than what evolutionists say, then their theory must be overthrown. They say the evolution of new traits happens gradually through the population over thouands/millions of years through random mutation via selection...I say it happens instantly, within the lifetime of the individual animal...no selection needed. 
 
 I also say new traits emerge in offspring nonrandomly in response to environmental cues. These traits form during development or even afterwards during the lifetime of the animal. New traits can be a result of plasticity or in the form of mutation during development. If the mutation occurs in somatic cells, only the individual (parent) organism is affected. If the mutation occurs in the germ cell, the mutation may pass on to the next generation -- though not necessarily expressed in the parent in which it arose.

 Supersport, I challenge you to arrange to have your next child born and raised in inland Antarctica. If you are correct, God's design will ensure that your child is adequately suited to the environment with minimal help from its parents. According to your position, your child may very well look like a penguin, but it will be your child nonetheless, and I'm sure you'll love him or her just as much as your other children (who may or may not have elected to join you in your South Pole escapades for science.) This will allow you to test your hypothesis of plasticity engaged not only during development but also "on-the-fly."
 
 I look forward to hearing from you in a couple years. Please document your experiences with video and a well-detailed laboratory notebook.

 Somehow it seems to have escaped the author's notice that his research is undermining evolutionary theory. In fact, he - and the rest of us on this board - can see very clearly how the mechanisms he's investigating fit elegantly within the prevailing evolutionary paradigm. Odd how you're the only one who sees otherwise. Ah, but then - you believe it must be otherwise, so it must be. QED.
